cool! I had to convince myself that mutation of the engine's mode had effect:

      def test_crypto_engine_reuse(self):
        plaintext = b'plain as can be' * 10
        key = os.urandom(32)
        iv1 = os.urandom(16)
        engine1 = Cipher(algorithms.AES(key), modes.CTR(iv1),
                         backend=self.crypto.backend)
        ciphertext1 = engine1.encryptor().update(plaintext)

        iv2 = os.urandom(16)
        engine2 = Cipher(algorithms.AES(key), modes.CTR(iv2),
                         backend=self.crypto.backend)
        ciphertext2 = engine2.encryptor().update(plaintext)
        self.assertNotEqual(ciphertext1, ciphertext2)

        # now decrypt both ciphertexts using the same engine...
        engine = Cipher(algorithms.AES(key), modes.CTR(iv1),
                        backend=self.crypto.backend)
        decryptor1 = engine.decryptor()
        plaintext1 = decryptor1.update(ciphertext1)

        engine.mode = modes.CTR(iv2)
        decryptor2 = engine.decryptor()
        plaintext2 = decryptor2.update(ciphertext2)
        self.assertEqual(plaintext, plaintext1)
        self.assertEqual(plaintext, plaintext2)

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Since the commit that introduced this glance-api extended grace period has no additional info about why it should be so high and OpenStack Helm already merged a change that decreases it (https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstack-helm/+/836329) I think it is a safe change.

This really seems like someone was trying to run away from a problem as a 10m SIGTERM timeout for a simple service like Glance is very weird. So I really dont see a problem in reducing this timeout.

However if 10m are passing and Glance is receiving a SIGKILL I would like to know why,do you know why glance cant actually gracefully terminate?

basically, how do we know if we would not run into a new problem SIGKILLing glance everytime?

Well, as I investigated it, the Glance don't gracefully terminate due to a authenticate with kube-apiserver  with the error: "Unable to authenticate the request" err="[invalid bearer token, Token has been invalidated]"

The logs doesn't have much information about it, but when I was researching it I saw that it can be a timing error between the communication of the kube-apiserver and the glance-api when is in terminating state. I ran the test that test the gracefully terminate for 25x and couldn't see the problem. Normally, the glance api terminate gracefully before 30sec, but if the error of Unable to authenticate appear, it kill faster to keep the things working like the other services does.
Thanks for the reviews, fast-approving now, feel free to push a change if something needs to be updated.

Perhaps suggest trying to reproduce locally if convenient when revising, too? That increases confidence the next test run won't be wasted on the same problem. Also if your patch gets multiple failed jobs, don't simply assume all are caused by a single problem. It would be unfortunate to notice a pedantic whitespace issue raised by a linter, fix and push that only to see that there are other jobs failing on deeper issues in your code which you could have spotted sooner if only you had looked past the first failed job.

I tried to say that on L152. I could say IRC specifically if you think it's important, but there are other methods that may be better, like the mailing list. This is already pretty verbose, so I didn't want to try to list/explain how to do that as well.
Note I'm not aware of any current tracking based on this. But having the comments in a consistent format would enable API queries to do this.

Sort of. The precursor to elastic-recheck was a recheck tracker which correlated bug numbers, but we quickly discovered that it was a pointless exercise (from an analysis perspective) because of bad actors poisoning the data with random bug numbers. The current iteration of elastic-recheck associates known failure patterns in job logs with bug reports or other identifiers, in an attempt to provide a more accurate alternative.

I thought we used that format for elastic recheck accounting back in the day. However, what I meant by tracking here is bugs we've got marked as "gate blocker" which are tracked by the project team and not necessarily any sort of actual mechanical "a recheck against this bug adds points automatically" or any sort of thing.

Right, that's what I meant. I know it was a failure to induce widespread proper behavior and that's why we're not trying to encourage everyone to do that here. The point of recommending it here is just keeping with that goal of also getting people to file or find bugs that refer to gate failures, but not imply that there's any actual mechanical linkage. I think what we've got here is fine as it is, even though it evokes baggage for us old baggage-laden people :)

/COMMIT_MSG.message: According to the bug descirption, it says two public networks produce two same floating IP. I cannot imagine how could this happen in a real production environment. Floating IP always means public IP, it will be accessible from outside world, in such case, those can not be in service at same time. Cloud provider can not sell one IP to more than one user. For such purely experimental testing, IMO, it should be prohibited from the API layer.

Those external networks for OpenStack doesn't need to have access to internet. We have this deployment in learning environments: several private networks connected to separate external networks, each one in an independent physical network. The CIDRs of the external networks are the same. Of course, we can't use QoS there now.

External network doesn't mean that this network has connectivity to internet.

[1] is checking the subnet CIDRs for a single router. In the case of this bug, the L3 agent and the QoS extension is handling all the routers hosted in this node in a single place. Duplicated FIP addresses (from different registers) can be stored in the same dictionaries.

Instead of adding any artificial limitation, this bug should be fixed in this patch. It is valid to have this configuration and we should not limit that; same as with many other features, the user is responsible of the deployment administration and configuration.

[1]https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/db/l3_db.py#L643-L683

I was expecting this answer.

The problem is not if this is something usual but if it is possible. You can have two separate physical networks and external networks on them, with the same CIDR. Why not?

Please, provide a real reason to block this (and how) from the API layer.
Done

Rodolfo - I agree that we should allow this config, but it's clear the external/public/floating network wording is causing confusion again (as it always has). I guess the way I think of it here is that each one of these subnets is behind an upstream NAT perhaps, so what CIDR we use doesn't matter. It's ugly from that perspective but does have its (limited) use case.

Please, find in the documentation where "external" network means internet connection. If so, we should change the scope of this bug. An external network [1] is:

"Any given Networking set up has at least one external network. Unlike the other networks, the external network is not merely a virtually defined network. Instead, it represents a view into a slice of the physical, external network accessible outside the OpenStack installation. IP addresses on the external network are accessible by anybody physically on the outside network."

That means, this network is a connection to an upper infrastructure, outside OpenStack. That does not imply internet connectivity and there is no limitation to have multiple overlapped CIDRs in independent and isolated external networks.

The goal of this patch is to be able to handle duplicated FIP.ip_address from different FIP resources. This patch won't affect at all (as it should be) to any existing deployment.

[1]https://docs.openstack.org/newton/install-guide-rdo/neutron-concepts.html

"""
I cannot imagine how could this happen in a real production environment. Floating IP always means public IP, it will be accessible from outside world, in such case, those can not be in service at same time. Cloud provider can not sell one IP to more than one user. 
"""

I will repeat such opinions, no idea how could this be possible in real production environment. For most cases of cloud providers, floating IP (sometiems they called it public IP, Elastic IP, and so on) is an uniq address which only belongs to one user for one use (application).

Two same IPs can come from different physical networks and external networks, but how these IPs are announced on Internet? URL is mapping to one IP address, so outside world will access which IP finally? (I'm almost lost here, it is ONE IP, why I use "which" here 😕) And one interesting thing is, cloud you use 8.8.8.8 to your cloud again? 😊 It is uniquely assigned by ICANN.

Regarding to the API restriction, [1] can be an example for checking the overlapping of external network and router interface (network). New API restriction can aligin such check. And also I will ask a question, why not we remove such restriction [1]? If user can ensure the floating IP and port fixed IP are not same, then it is possible to work.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/db/l3_db.py#L643-L683

From my personal experiences, the most common use of floating IP and external network is for accessing Internet. If not, maybe Neutron should re-define what are "external" network and "floating" IP. And if openstack is mainly for learning environments, IMO, it will be dead shortly afterwards. 😊

For the issue you mentioned here, which is mainly becasue that in one cloud environment floating IPs are not treated as an UNIQUE resource. If it is unique, no issue as it is, right?

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Still not completely clear to me why we need to do this.  Is there a non-explicit module dependency chain of some sort?  Some intertwining of Mellanox and the RDMA in bnxt?  Is there some concise wording somewhere that explains the dependency?

Thanks for the feedback.

Regarding loading modules unconditionally, I started to have the same thoughts.

Sounds good, I will amend the commit message as well.

Hi Jim,

Thank you for the review, and sorry for this issue. I tried to mention this in the same paragraph:

```
While the bnxt_en module has aliases that allows it to be automatically
loaded on systems with applicable network adapters, the bnxt_re module
does not. This in turn requires users to manually load the bnxt_re
module when RDMA over Converged Ethernet (RoCE) functionality is desired
on systems with compatible adapters.
```

In summary, the Infiniband/RDMA-related programs do *not* trigger the kernel to automatically load the bnxt_re module. However, without the bnxt_re module, it is not possible to use RDMA over Ethernet. For this reason, I opted to load bnxt_en and bnxt_re automatically. (My understanding is that Mellanox's Infiniband kernel modules are automatically loaded via /etc/modules-load.d for the same reason.)

I could perhaps not include bnxt_en in the list of modules to auto-load, as it will be automatically loaded in case a matching PCI device is detected.

I would appreciate further feedback. Thanks again.

FWIW, I'm NOT a fan of loading driver modules where there is no corresponding hardware.  Keeping out bnxt_en if there is no hardware, is preferred.

Saying something short and sweet like "We have to autoload the bnxt_re module because nothing else is going to pull it in on reference.  This is the same behaviour as for Mellanox's infiniband modules." is pretty much all you need.  Any more explaining just tends to add confusion.
Done.

The 'install' hook will eventually deprecate (as described in the man pages) so I agree it is not the best choice. But the 'softdep' hook is available. Why is this solution less complicated or preferred?

Done. I opted for softdep to avoid loading the modules when compatible hardware is not available.

One counter-argument would be behavioural consistency for finding possible issues. If we have a bug that exists only when bnxt_en and/or bnxt_re are loaded, then we would catch that bug earlier if we ensure that bnxt_en and bnxt_re are always loaded in general. One example of this is how kdump fails due to running out of memory when large kernel modules are loaded. This issue does not exist for bnxt_en/bnxt_re, because I excluded them from the kdump initramfs, but such an issue would be caught earlier if we always load bnxt_en/bnxt_re by default. In any case, this is a minor benefit, I think.

Hi Mark,

Thanks for recommending the use of a softdep hook. I have used install hooks a lot in the past, but I have not used softdep at all, hence the reason why I did not realize that it would be a better candidate here.

For the install hook, I had thought of using an additional script like the following, which is why I had thought that using a modules-load.d would have been simpler to implement:

/etc/modprobe.d/bnxt.conf
```
install bnxt_en /usr/sbin/load_bnxt.sh $CMDLINE_OPTS
```

/usr/sbin/load_bnxt.sh
```
#!/bin/bash -e

modprobe --ignore-install bnxt_en "${@}"
modprobe bnxt_re
```

On a second thought, I realize now that an external script is not really necessary, and arguably complicates things further, so the simplicity argument is moot as well.

I realize that I have not considered all possible solutions. I will update the patch to use the softdep hook. Testing with an actual target may take a while as the lab system is not available for me any longer, so I will use a VM instead.

Thanks for having a look. I am not sold on one way being better vs. the other but I believe there are some advantages to using softdep vs. the more brute force technique you opted for. Give it a look, we might find pitfalls which tip the scales back to your solution. We shall see.

neutron/services/trunk/drivers/openvswit.message: wondering why this does not prevent trunk bridge removal in case port is re-added?

Looking at the definition of function bridge_has_instance_port (line 98 above), we get true here if we find a port that is not a trunk service port, i.e. if we find a port whose name doesn't start with 'tp' or 'sp'. Please look at line 1 here: https://paste.openstack.org/show/bjJDTSXYj95NpaSjxHsx/. The interface 'vhu7003efbf-21' (the instance port) has been removed from bridge 'tbr-6fa74ed9-4' and that's why this greenthread is started by line 152 above in the first place. This is the only instance port, so execution continues in line 230 below. 

What happens next is that Nova (via os-vif) very quickly adds the same interface again (line 11 in https://paste.openstack.org/show/bjJDTSXYj95NpaSjxHsx/), because the corresponding instance is being rebooted. But by then, we already executed bridge_has_instance_port and we are well on our way to delete the trunk resources, as you can see in the log's lines 5 and 7, but right before we delete delete the bridge (line 13 in the same log)
What happens if we haven't yet received a notification to create it again? Where will trunk bridge be recreated?

@Rodolfo,

"This "unplug" method uses a transaction context; that means the port and the trunk deletion will be done together. In the "bridge" register, in the "external_ids" dictionary field, I would include the timestamp. In the "inplug" transaction I would check if the timestamp has been updated recently (in the last second) and I would skip/continue depending on this."

So you are suggesting that here https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/5c47957e89062c1e99b6e7dc28e96eff52ce514e/neutron/services/trunk/drivers/openvswitch/agent/trunk_manager.py#L138-L141 in one transaction we:

1) Check that the time stamp in the bridge's external_ids is less than x seconds old. If not, return. If yes then....
2) Delete the bridge
3) Delete the port

How do you express these three steps above in such a way that it is one OVSDB transaction?

Thanks Rodolfo.

I may be missing something but:

Let's say that we add a timestamp to the bridge in this transaction: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/os-vif/+/830103/1/vif_plug_ovs/ovsdb/ovsdb_lib.py#183

What prevents the execution of this transaction in os-vif between the bridge lookup and the bridge deletion in the code you propose for the neutron agent in your previous response? The way I see it is that the following sequence is perfectly possible:

1) We retrieve in the neutron agent with the bridge lookup you propose above a time stamp that is more than 1 second old
2) The compute agent executes the code in the with block here https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/os-vif/+/830103/1/vif_plug_ovs/ovsdb/ovsdb_lib.py#180 and upon reaching the end of the block the transaction is sent to the OVSDB server via the OVS IDL
3) We delete the bridge anyways in the neutron agent because in step 1 we have the old time stamp, not the most recent one

In other words, the bridge lookup is not executed within the OVSDB transaction that is being created in the code you propose above. It executes independently of that transaction. It just happens to be in the same with block

The chances for this to happen are very low. Even with the possibility, this method to sync os-vif and Neutron is more robust than the current one.

The next step could be to modify the OVS API (and OvsdbVsctl until we remove it), adding a new parameter to "del_br", that could be a deletion condition. I wouldn't make this condition too complicated: just a parameter that will be the "ts_update" and will be a float. ovsdbapp will check, in "DelBridgeCommand", the external_ids:ts_update stored and will compare it. If provided "ts_updated" is greater than the one stored, the bridge should be deleted. That check will happen during the txn commit.

BTW, to check this you can use "OVSBridgeTestBase". I've implemented this code using the existing FT code [1]. It could be more useful.

[1]https://paste.opendev.org/show/btlxUlpTcWgX4ZFZTQoT/

So is my understanding correct: if new port notification comes after execution passes line 242 - the bridge will be deleted and we would still have an issue? In your opinion what's the chance that this new port notification will always come before line 242? Sorry, I might still miss something
I see the same, with the os-vif change together the plug will be transaction like, so the situation is much better.

Ohh! Yeah, I see @Rodolfo's point. It is always possible that the transaction on the os-vif side may completely execute after line 242 and before we execute the transaction in the trunk unplug. I'll work on this tomorrow

I would use ovs_idl.Backend.lookup, something like this:

ovsdb = self.bridge.ovsdb
with ovsdb.transaction() as txn:
     br = ovsdb.lookup('Bridge', self.bridge.br_name, default=None)
     if br:
         ts_update = float(br.external_ids.get('ts_update', 0))
         delta = compare_timestamps(ts_update)
         if delta < 1:  # This bridge has been updated right now.
             return

     txn.add(ovsdb.del_br(self.bridge.br_name))
     txn.add(ovsdb.del_port(self.patch_port_int_name,
             bridge.br_name))


def compare_timestamps(before, after=None):
    # Input: float, float
    # Returns a floating number, up to microseconds
    after = (datetime.datetime.timestamp(after)
             if after or datetime.datetime.now())
    before = datetime.datetime.timestamp(before)
    return (after - after).total_seconds()

As explained in my response above (line 226) we indeed receive the notification that the instance port has been added again (line 11 in the log) but we have handle_trunk_add waiting for the trunk bridge semaphore ("tbr-6fa74ed9-4" in our example). When this greenthread releases the semaphore (line 19 in the log), handle_trunk_add acquires it (line 21 in the log) and then fails miserably because the bridge is gone. It is this race condition that I am trying to fix.

@Rodolfo,

Based on your previous response and after reading https://rodolfo-alonso.com/ovsdbapp-your-library-for-open-vswitch-and-ovn, I devised this experiment to run inside a devstack: https://gist.github.com/miguellavalle/2200d0c48cec0c9b7308cd44c4eb78a4.

Here's how the experiment works:

1) connect_ovsdb.py is just a copy of the code you have in your blog entry, so I can import it in neutron_agent.py and os_vif.py.

2) I run neutron_agent.py and while it is sleeping, I run os_vif.py. My expectation was that os_vif.py was going to be delayed by the open transaction in neutron_agent.py. That's not what happens, though. os_vif.py finishes right away.

What am I doing wrong?

Right, bridge can be deleted between L242 and L243.

But this patch should be complemented with [1]. That means Nova now creates the bridge and the port in the same OVSDB txn. That will be detected by the OVS monitor and the event captured by "process_trunk_port_events".

Of course there is chance of race condition here, as you commented. I would improve this feature using again, as in [1], the OVSDB transactionality: the "remove_trunk" method calls "trunk.unplug". This "unplug" method uses a transaction context; that means the port and the trunk deletion will be done together. In the "bridge" register, in the "external_ids" dictionary field, I would include the timestamp. In the "inplug" transaction I would check if the timestamp has been updated recently (in the last second) and I would skip/continue depending on this. Of course, that implies Nova compute and Neutron OVS agent should be sync (they are running in the same host, they should).

[1]https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/os-vif/+/830103

ovsdbapp IDL implementation is transactionally safe but with writing commands (those ones you actually add to the txn context). But the lookup methods read from the IDL local cache [1]. Thus we are txn safe for write commands but the read ones are not.

This is why in this example, "ts_update" will have an older value, read before "os_vif.py" sets "ts_update=3".

The OVS DB transactionality will prevent from deleting and creating the bridge at the same time. And the timestamp will let Neutron know if this bridge has been created in the last second or less, that implies the creation has been triggered again just before the previous deletion and this deletion should be stopped.


[1] from the article: "The IDL instance (Interface Definition Language) mantains a in-memory replica of the database. Here is where we go when we execute a database read command, instead of creating a transaction, building a query and executing this query on the OVSDB server."

@Rodolfo,

The upshot of your latest explanation (""The IDL instance (Interface Definition Language) mantains a in-memory replica of the database. Here is where we go when we execute a database read command, instead of creating a transaction, building a query and executing this query on the OVSDB server.") is that ovsdb.lookup will not serve us to serialize the transactions in the neutron agent and os-vif. Let me explain. Please look at this gist: https://gist.github.com/miguellavalle/d04f8e660afdd5cf06b86cebfeab316e. Let's say we run the two programs in parallel. A possible scenario is one in which:

1) neutron_agent.py executes up to line 12 and decides to execute line 13, but just before actually executing it...

2) os_vif.py executes completely

3) neutron_agent.py resumes, executes line 13 and deletes the bridge, even though it shouldn't have because the bridge has been updated very recently

As I said in one of my previous comments, in neutron_agent.py the bridge lookup and the decision to delete the bridge happen outside the transaction.

Based on this, I think we have 3 alternatives:

1) If in the case of vhost user each trunk bridge only has one instance port, why don't we let os-vif delete the bridge when it unplugs the vif. That way the bridge deletion and it subsequent re-addition will be perfectly serialized.

2) If the previous point is not feasible, we could implement a periodic job that deletes, for the vhost user case, "stale" bridges that have not been used in a certain period of time. The period can be even configurable by the user

3) Looking at https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7047.txt#section-5.2 and more specifically at https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7047.txt#section-5.2.5, it seems that the json-rpc protocol allows to specify a where clause in a delete operation. It doesn't seem to me that ovsdbapp gives access to that feature, but maybe we can explore using it, so we delete only "stale" bridges in a transaction

(2) can't happen if you have started (1). In (1), we have already started a transaction, thus os-vif can't create the bridge at the same time.

If we are already in (1), then Neutron will delete the bridge. Then os-vif will create it again.

If os-vif creates the port some msecs before Neutron tries to delete the bridge, this condition will abort this deletion.

> You just point the ovsdb connection string to the backup node.

Since version 2.13.3 of python-ovs, the ovsdb IDL module automatically connects to the leader node of ovn-nb and ovn-sb.
If you want to control the ovsdb idl connection to the backup node, you need to modify the python-ovs library to achieve it, so it is not recommended
> > 2) when the metadata is created, it performs just one write. Do we improve the performance removing this write command?
> 
> Removing the write doesn't improve performance, it's just that it is impossible to write to the backup since it is read-only. So removing the write is necessary to be able to use backup servers.
by the DB backup node it means backup in Pacemaker, not in the RAFT cluster. It means we set IPs of all nodes and agent will not perform any write operation.
Understood: we can point to a backup node (that cannot be used to write) and just execute read operations. Perfect.

Is this relevant with RAFT? Need to any notes to the commit msg/reno?
I think it's still relevant. It doesn't change how and to what nodes metadata agent connects but if they report its status or not. I think the raft doesn't play a role here.

i think it does play a role. The seed of this patch was the performance and scale issues with non RAFT OVN dbs. Otherwise we wouldn’t be doing this, the same way we don’t do it for any other Neutron agent. Am I right?

Yes, there were also other patches because of that. However, this patch in isolation just disables reporting. It doesn't make any change of how agents connect to the nodes. For RAFT vs. pcmk you'd need to reconfigure the connection strings which was already done in other patches for different projects. Those patches are useless if agent keeps writing.

Feels like disabling the agent reporting is to workaround a limitation that is addressed now properly with RAFT.
if feels weird to disable reporting just here now while the other neutron agents don’t have the option (maybe they do?).
in any case, I understand the rationale of this (hence I +1’ed) but just making sure that it is the direction we want to take.

Those other projects (TripleO) will enable just RAFT and no pacemaker - not even optionally -. in such case we probably won’t ever need this patch at all. In isolation, with other deployers, maybe it makes sense but still it feels like a workaround for a deeper problem.

that said I keep my +1 :)

swift/common/db.py.message: nit: We could drop this clause -- it'll get handled by the for loop anyway,
When would we pass in a False-y pending_shards value? Or are we just being defensive?
Just being defensive. But happy to remove it if we "trust" ourselves :P

What happens if somebody takes this lock and dies/hangs so it's never released? Currently on master, we'll start seeing a ton of lock timeouts popping, which'll be a decent signal to ops to investigate -- restart container-server and if that doesn't fix it, reboot the node.

As it is, looks like we'll just balloon the many pending files...

Maybe we could do something with skipping any pending files that are already at the cap, and throwing an error if that means we don't have anywhere left to put it?
Good idea. I'll raise an error for now. Another option is to allow them to balloon but once they get bigger then the pending_cap start logging a warning for OPs.
What happens when one of these times out?

So my thinking was, if we

* process one pending file, merging its items with the one we just got from the client,
* call merge_items() to get all that into the DB, but then
* pop a lock timeout on the next pending file

we return an error to the client even though we *could* justifiably return success. The trouble, of course, is differentiating it (as a caller) from the case when the timeout pops on the first file (so we *haven't* written down the client's row).

I'm probably just over-thinking it, though -- we definitely want "all succeed or raise a timeout" behavior in the read path, for example, so it's probably best & simplest to impose that everywhere. I was just thinking about whether the new partial-failure case might warrant different handling in some cases.
hmm, I hope we get it next time?

We don't bomb out, though -- we just skip this entry.

*Does* make me think that logger.exception() probably isn't appropriate, though -- there isn't much of anything the stack trace will tell us that we couldn't pick up from the distinctive error message. Might could use a reference to the actual error, though.
We should clear item_list once we call merge_items to avoid quadratic behaviors.
I wonder if these would be more obvious if we used self.db_file / self.db_dir ...

I wonder if we might want to shuffle these before processing, similar to what we do when we're filling them.

Basically, in case there's some weird thing where we're frequently unable to process all the files -- the first few files might get cleared, but then there's a lock timeout or something, and none of the rest get processed, so they just keep filling. Once we've got something in place where we're unwilling to write to a shard that's larger than the pending cap, that'll shrink the set of available pending files such that even though you've configured 10 files (say), you're only able to make use of 2 or something.
yeah, we shuffle on the other side, we should also do it here. Great idea!

swift/common/utils.py.message: If everybody's locked... I'm not sure we'll ever trip the timeout. We want this outside the for loop.
Definitely *don't* want the yield inside the LockTimeout -- the guy that *succeeds* in getting the lock can have a LockTimeout pop in the middle of its work!

I was thinking, since we already call getsize() on everybody in the caller, we could just filter the filenames we pass in. Sure, there could be a write between then and when we actually manage to take the lock, but I don't think we actually need a *hard* cap -- just something to make sure these guys don't grow without bound.

oh, I didn't even think about that. So that could make it more of a soft block. Once it gets into this function it's a viable file to return. Also love that we could use the existing getsize values and save some extra IO.
I think we leave a file descriptor open here. Also, if there's any *other* sort of error raised...

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: I'm fine with such config option as by default it will not change Neutron's behavior but I think it deserves for the release note

I'm not particularly in favor of this change. The API allows to, once the SG is created and the default egress rules, remove the created rules.

If something like this is going to be implemented, I would use a more explicit way: modifying the API and allowing a new parameter, passed via CLI. This parameter (something like "--no-default-egress-rules") would be something explicit, defined per SG, not a "hidden" configuration parameter applicable to all the deployment.

I know this last idea is more complicated to implement but (1) is flexible (per SG) and (2) is explicit (you specify it in the CLI).

Yeah well customer wants to drop all traffic by default and force users to add the required flows.   Ideally, it would be better to have a default SG with default rules that we apply to each new created groups which would avoid having this new argument --no-default-egres-rules or the parameter I we just implemented in this patch.   I'll let you decide over this but I don't think those 2 ideas are the best ideas as the best idea is still the global default security group idea which was declined many times.

The "default" security group is something created by default when no SG is created yet in this this project. However, if any admin needs something more specific (for example, no egress rules or no rules at all), a specific SG can be created and used. The API currently allows this operation.

I'm not in favor of adding more config knobs and even less if this is something doable with the current API.

Maybe we should allow both approach here ?    There're cases where users would like to have the same kind of behavior in egress as the ingress flows which is to disable everything by default and punch holes in the FW as flows require.

https://docs.python.org/3/library/warnings.html#default-warning-filter

Oh, that's a good point -- maybe it'd be better if I used FutureWarning? From the docs, that's

> for warnings about deprecated features when those warnings are intended for end users of applications that are written in Python

as opposed to DeprecationWarning which is

> for warnings about deprecated features when those warnings are intended for other Python developers

Since EC scheme is typically user-configurable, it seems like this ought to be more of a user-facing warning, rather than developer-facing.

Further reading:
- https://docs.python.org/3/library/warnings.html#warning-categories
- https://peps.python.org/pep-0565/

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Maybe still check the ensure parameter is not given in testing to ensure nothing modifies it in the future?

I'm not sure how you want to proceed, but I'm struggling to decide how puppet should handle driver parameters that really don't feel like they should be optional, even if the cinder code has a blank string for some default values.

manifests/backend/san.pp.message:
I have no idea whether cinder's SAN backend is in widespread use in 2022, but the code that added support for it is quite old. The cinder driver dates back to 2012 and the puppet-cinder resource in 2014.

I mention this because I suspect puppet-cinder's use of 'undef' for parameters like this may have been influenced by the cinder driver's default value of '' (blank string) [1].

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/src/branch/master/cinder/volume/drivers/san/san.py#L44

This is very odd, because nothing will work unless the user provides a valid IP address for their device. I believe the cinder driver's option should not have any default value, and the corresponding puppet-cinder argument should be required (not optional).

The san_password is another example of something that doesn't seem like there would be any valid default value, unless it's related to the san_private_key parameter. Maybe you need to define only one of them, and the other can be left blank? I don't know enough about the SAN driver, and it doesn't look like there's is much code activity in that area.

I understand that point and actually I feel the current implementation in puppet-cinder is "incomplete" and needs some improvement to validate the required parameters.

However parameter validation is a different topic, IMO. The current implementation does not require these parameters because of the default value (undef) and does not fail even if a user doesn't give the parameters required to make the driver functional. This issue is not fixed or changed by my change. The only difference is the new implementation removes the parameter by default, but this doesn't cause difference because the cinder.conf file provided by packages do not include effective parameters (but only comment lines) by default.

Ideally we need to introduce a validation to ensure the required parameters are given. I'll look into that later, but it would requires some effort to dig into cinder code, so I'd leave that as a separate topic.
Although I suspect there aren't any actual deployments that will benefit, I do agree the change will avoid parameters like this becoming unmanaged.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: We now have correct rpm, this patch is not needed anymore.
LGTM, Thank you for back porting
